docs.lead_paragraph: The family of a cancer victim took France's formerly state-owned cigarette company to court today in the first trial of its kind in this nation, where smoky cafes remain a cultural signature. The family of Richard Gourlain, 49, who died of lung and larynx cancer in January, continued with a lawsuit he had brought against the tobacco company, Seita, before his death. Mr. Gourlain smoked up to three packs of unfiltered Gauloise cigarettes a day for many years.
docs.abstract: Family of Richard Gourlain, smoker who died of cancer, continues his suit against French tobacco company Seita, in first trial of its kind in France; suit charges company provided insufficient data about health risks of smoking; local insurance company is civil party in suit, seeking reimbursement for his treatment (M)
docs.snippet: The family of a cancer victim took France's formerly state-owned cigarette company to court today in the first trial of its kind in this nation, where smoky cafes remain a cultural signature.     The family of Richard Gourlain, 49, who died of lung...

docs.lead_paragraph: Judging by the number of colorful advertisements and fliers on the city's subways and buses offering podiatry services, one would think New Yorkers' foot problems have reached epidemic proportions. But maybe the problems are not all in the feet. Yesterday, Federal prosecutors said they had charged 13 podiatrists with conspiring in an elaborate scheme to lure elderly and poor patients in New York with fliers offering free foot examinations, only to bill their health insurers and the Federal Medicare program for expensive surgeries and other therapies that were never performed.

headline.main: 13 Podiatrists Named in Plot To Clip More Than Toenails

docs.abstract: Federal prosecutors charge 13 podiatrists with conspiring in elaborate scheme to lure elderly and poor patients in New York City with fliers offering free foot examinations, only to bill their health insurers and Federal Medicare program for expensive surgeries and other therapies that were never performed (M)
docs.snippet: Judging by the number of colorful advertisements and fliers on the city's subways and buses offering podiatry services, one would think New Yorkers' foot problems have reached epidemic proportions.    But maybe the problems are not all in the feet.  ...

docs.lead_paragraph: Six years ago, when Pandora Singleton founded a support group for H.I.V.-positive women in Savannah, Ga., drug executives rarely knocked on her door to offer financing or information about the virus. All that has changed.

headline.main: A Movable Epidemic; Makers of AIDS Drugs Struggle to Keep Up With Market

docs.abstract: Drug companies scramble to introduce AIDS drugs to new types of patients, as profile of those who have AIDS broadens to include women, Hispanic people and blacks; demographic change comes at precarious time for makers of AIDS drugs; worldwide market for such drugs ballooned 123 percent, to $3.47 billion, from 1996 to 1997, but has begun to slow sharply; analysts cite several factors: that demand for drugs was so great that it hit its sales peaks quickly, that market for HIV drugs has become crowded, and that many women or low-income members of minorities do not have health insurance or thorough knowledge of illness and are not always easy to reach; photos; charts (M)
docs.snippet: Six years ago, when Pandora Singleton founded a support group for H.I.V.-positive women in Savannah, Ga., drug executives rarely knocked on her door to offer financing or information about the virus.    All that has changed.

docs.lead_paragraph: The Senate majority leader, Trent Lott, said today that President Clinton's promised veto of the Republicans' $792 billion tax-cut bill probably doomed any tax-relief legislation this year and would set up a major campaign issue for the 2000 election. In the opening salvo of the biggest political battle in Washington this fall, Mr. Lott all but ruled out any compromise with the White House, saying there was not enough time to negotiate a new plan for taxes and spending for the next decade.

headline.main: Lott Says Veto Is Likely to Kill Tax Cut in '99

docs.abstract: Sen Trent Lott says Pres Clinton's promised veto of Republicans' $792 billion tax-cut bill probably dooms any tax-relief bill this year and will be major campaign issue; all but rules out any compromise; Rep Tom DeLay backs stand, but other Republican leaders are willing to discuss smaller tax package, especially repeal of estate tax or so-called marriage tax; both Republicans and Democrats believe failure to cut taxes will not be politically costly; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: INFOCURE CORP., Atlanta, a maker of health-care practice management software, agreed to buy closely held Datamedic Holding Corp., Waltham, Mass., a provider of practice-management and clinical-systems services for 10,000 United States doctors, for about $25.4 million in stock.

docs.lead_paragraph: Following are excerpts from a speech yesterday by Bill Bradley in Crystal City, Mo., as recorded by The New York Times: We're at a special moment in American history, not just because we're on the eve of a new millennium but because our country and the world are changing at a dazzling rate. There are two billion more people in the world market today than just a decade ago. More of our jobs are dependent on exports than ever.

headline.main: Excerpts From Bradley's Announcement of Candidacy

docs.lead_paragraph: Following are excerpts from an address on health care yesterday by Vice President Al Gore at the Children's Hospital of Los Angeles, as recorded by The New York Times: For more than 50 years we have been engaged in a battle to provide the kind of health care a great nation owes its people. Now after that long century of effort, conflict and concern, it is time to move past theoretical and philosophical divisions beyond a sterile debate about labels and abstractions to ask what we can do now to take concrete, specific, realistic steps to improve health coverage for all of the American people. Today I'm proposing and with your help as President, I will fight for a series of steps to do just that. We must and we can insure a set of rights so that all Americans can have health coverage and actually get the care they are -- all Americans who have health coverage, will get the care they are entitled to. We must and we can secure access to affordable quality health care for every child in the entire country by the year 2005. Join with me and we will do that. We must and we can move toward access to affordable, quality health care for every American family.

headline.main: Excerpts From Gore's Speech on Care

docs.abstract: Excerpts from address on health care by Vice President Al Gore at Children's Hospital of Los Angeles (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Vice President Al Gore proposed today to guarantee access to affordable health insurance for all children by 2005, expanding on a program enacted two years ago that he conceded had had limited success so far. Mr. Gore acknowledged that the number of Americans without health coverage had increased steadily since he and President Clinton took office. But in a speech at Children's Hospital of Los Angeles, in Hollywood, he said, ''If you elect me President, I will insure that by the year 2005, every single child in our country has full access to fully affordable health coverage.''

headline.main: Gore Pledges A Health Plan For Every Child

docs.abstract: Vice Pres Al Gore proposes guaranteed access to health insurance for all children by 2005, expanding on program enacted two years ago that he concedes has had limited success so far; acknowledges in speech at Children's Hospital of Los Angeles that number of Americans without health coverage has increased since he and Pres Clinton took office, but vows all children will have full access to fully affordable health coverage if he is elected President; criticizes Rebublican Presidential frontrunner Texas Gov George W Bush, noting that one-fourth of children in Texas lack insurance--higher proportion than almost any other state; offers proposals to increase coverage of adults, including new tax credit to offset 25 percent of cost of health insurance bought by individuals who lack access to employer-sponsored coverage; principal goals of his health-care initiative outlined; number of uninsured children rose by roughly 2.5 million in last decade, to 11 million in 1997; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL A3-12 U.N. Says East Timorese Are Forced Across Border As many as 200,000 people, nearly a quarter of East Timor's population, have been driven from their homes by militias opposed to independence for the territory, the United Nations said. Many displaced people who sought refuge in churches and aid agencies are being rounded up and forcibly moved across the border to Indonesian West Timor, a United Nations spokesman said, citing a report from the United Nations mission in East Timor. A1
